TemplateInfo.Name: SWITCH - Policy Effects of Base vs. Reform
TemplateInfo.Title: SWITCH - Policy Effects of Base vs. Reform
TemplateInfo.Subtitle: Results for [baseCountry]: [baseSys] vs [refSysList]
TemplateInfo.GeneralDescription:
Income concepts:

Market/Original incomes are the sum of income from employment and self-employment plus income from other sources. Other sources include income from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16, minus private transfers paid to other assessment units.

Disposable incomes are the sum of market incomes and benefits (incl. pensions) minus taxes and social insurance contributions. Equivalised disposable income is the total disposable income of the assessment unit divided by the CSO equivalence scale to take differences in assessment unit composition into account. The CSO equivalence scale attributes a weight of 1 to the head of the unit, a weight of 0.66 to every person above the age of 13 and a weight of 0.33 to every child aged 0-13.

Decile groups are calculated by ranking tax units/income sharing units/households according to their equivalised disposable income in the baseline and dividing them into ten similar-sized groups.

Quintile groups are calculated by ranking tax units/income sharing units/households according to their equivalised disposable income in the baseline and dividing them into five similar-sized groups.

Poverty indicators:

Assessment units are defined as being at risk of poverty (poor) if their equivalised disposable income is below the poverty line.
The poverty line is defined as 60% of the median equivalised disposable income.
The poverty gap is calculated as the at risk of poverty rate, multiplied by the distance from the poverty line as a proportion of the poverty line.
The median income of people at-risk-of poverty is based on equivalised disposable income.

NOTE: negative equivalised disposable assessment unit incomes are recoded to 0 for all poverty related results.

Inequality indicators:

Gini measures the distribution of income where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

NOTE: negative incomes are recoded to 0 for results on the Gini indicator.

Page.Name: DecileRanges
Page.Title: Decile Ranges - Equivalised Disposable Income
Page.Description:
Deciles are built by grouping population into equal number of units (i.e. Tax Unit, Income Sharing Unit or Households) with respect to baseline equivalised disposable income of the unit.
The equivalence scale is that of the Central Statistics Office which attributes a weight of 1 to the first adult, 0.66 to each subsequent adult (aged 14+ living in the household) and 0.33 to each child aged less than 14.
Units with equal income are kept in the same decile, even if this leads to an unequal distribution of units over deciles.
Income and income changes as displayed in the tables refer to unequivalised disposable income.

Percentage Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by total baseline disposable income of the respective group.

Average Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by number of units in the respective group.

Aggregate Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Number of Cases:
Table shows number of units in the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Row Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of units in the respective decile type. Column Total is 100%.

Column Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of losers/no-change/gainers. Row All is 100%.

Page.Name: QuintileRanges
Page.Title: Quintile Ranges - Equivalised Disposable Income
Page.Description:
Quintiles are built by grouping population into equal number of units (i.e. Tax Unit, Income Sharing Unit or Households) with respect to baseline equivalised disposable income of the unit.
The equivalence scale is that of the Central Statistics Office which attributes a weight of 1 to the first adult, 0.66 to each subsequent adult (aged 14+ living in the household) and 0.33 to each child aged less than 14.
Units with equal income are kept in the same quintile, even if this leads to an unequal distribution of units over quiniles.
Income and income changes as displayed in the tables refer to unequivalised disposable income.

Percentage Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by total baseline disposable income of the respective group.

Average Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by number of units in the respective group.

Aggregate Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Number of Cases:
Table shows number of units in the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Row Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of units in the respective quintile. Column Total is 100%.

Column Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of losers/no-change/gainers. Row All is 100%.

Page.Name: FamilyType
Page.Title: Impact by Family Type
Page.Description:
The family type is defined based on the head of the tax-unit. The tax-unit head is defined by the person with the highest original income (ils_origy). If these are the same, the oldest person is the head and, in the event of a further tie, the person with the lowest personal id number is the head.
Income and income changes as displayed in the tables refer to unequivalised disposable income.

  • Single working-age without children: Head of tax-unit is aged 18-65 and neither a parent nor married/cohabitating
  • Lone parent: Head of tax-unit is aged 18-65, single and lone parent to a dependent child
  • Working age couple without children: Head of tax-unit is aged 18-65, is married/cohabitating but is not a parent
  • Working age couple with children: Head of tax-unit is aged 18-65, partner identifier>0 and is the parent to a dependent child
  • Single retirement age: Head of tax-unit is >=66 and is not married
  • Retirement age couple: Head of tax-unit is >=66 and is married/cohabitating. Note: partners aged <66 will be included in this category

Percentage Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by total baseline disposable income of the respective group.

Average Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group divided by number of units in the respective group.

Aggregate Change in Disposable Income:
Table shows total change in disposable income of the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Number of Cases:
Table shows number of units in the respective group. Column Total is the sum of the group columns. Row All is the sum of the group rows.

Row Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of units in the respective family type. Column Total is 100%.

Column Percentage Count:
Table shows number of units in the respective group divided by total number of losers/no-change/gainers. Row All is 100%.

Page.Name: SocialWelfare

Page.Name: Inequality
Page.Title: Basic Inequality Indices
Page.Subtitle: Primary statistical disclosure controls are applied.
Page.Description:
The table shows the Gini index for selected income concepts:

The comparison of the original income with the original income after taxes shows to what extent taxes contribute to redistribution.

The comparison of the original income plus public pensions after taxes with the original income after taxes shows the role of public pensions for redistribution.

The comparison of the original income with the disposable income shows the extent of income redistribution performed by the tax-benefit systems as a whole (incl. social insurance contributions and benefits beyond public pensions).

Column.Name: Gini Base
Column.Title: Gini [baseSysPretty]
Column.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

ReformColumn.Name: Gini Reform
ReformColumn.Title: Gini [refSysPretty]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

  • Children: younger than 18
  • Adults: aged between 18 and 65
  • Elderly: older than 65

Page.Name: NonCashBenefits
Page.Title: Non Cash Benefits - Expenditure & Recipients
Page.Subtitle: Primary statistical disclosure controls are applied.
Page.Description:
This table shows recipients of and expenditure on non-cash benefits.
The cost of Medical and GP visit cards is calculated based on usage of GP, dental, optometry, prescription medication and inpatient nights across age bands scaled by average costs of these services per card holder taken from annual PCRS publications.
The cost of the Early Childhood Care and Education Subsidy is calculated based on a fixed capitation fee paid per child enrolling in the scheme.
All calculations are at the individual level.

Page.Name: TaxIncentiveStats
Page.Title: Effects of Taxation on Incentives for Employment
Page.Description:
The following tables report three statistics that describe alternative measures of tax incentives for employment: marginal tax rates (MTRs), net replacement rates (NRRs) and participation tax rates (PTRs). MTRs report the tax rate applied to the last unit of currency earned from employment. A MTR is calculated for each individual with some employment income described by the input data (ils_earns > 0). NRRs report the proportional impact on disposable income of moving from employment to unemployment. NRRs are calculated both for any individual described by the input data with some employment income (ils_earns > 0), and for working aged individuals reported as unemployed (les = 5 or (les=7 & dag>18 & dag<65) or (les=9 & dag>18 & dag<65)). PTRs report the average effective tax rate applied to employment income. PTRs are calculated for the same population as considered for NRRs.

Income deciles are built by ranking the population by baseline equivalised disposable income, and then dividing the income parade into approximately equal numbers of tax units. The equivalence scale is the same as used by the Central Statistics Office, which attributes a weight of 1 to the first adult, 0.66 to each subsequent adult (aged 14+ living in the household) and 0.33 to each child aged less than 14. Units with equal income are allocated to the same decile, so that the total number of tax units may vary between decile groups.

Table.Title: Tax incentives by income decile (MTR, NRR and PTR in percentage points)
Tax incentives by family type (MTR, NRR and PTR in percentage points)
Histogram of MTRs (population count by MTR percentage point range)
Histogram of NRRs (population count by NRR percentage point range)
Histogram of PTRs (population count by PTR percentage point range)
